title: Skip This Nigerian Money-Making Opportunity
summary: The exchange-traded fund with the largest discount to net asset value on the market is less than meets the eye.

title: Aramco’s Dividend Discipline Isn’t Enough
summary: Oil industry investors have been rocked by two jarring dividend cuts this year, but the biggest oil company of them all has stayed the course. That discipline will do little to attract foreigners to Saudi Aramco, though.

title: PE Daily: Riverstone’s Soured Energy Bet | Clearlake Pitches Overage Fund | Sports Broadcasting Company Taps Restructuring Firm
summary: We kick off the week with a trio of stories that reflect the challenges private-equity firms and their portfolio companies have been under during the past few months of pandemic and economic turmoil.

title: Pandemic Triggers Wave of Long-Term Unemployment; Some Say 10-Year Treasury Note Isn’t What It Was
summary: The July U.S. jobs report showed an increasing number of workers have been unemployed for more than three months, a signal that the coronavirus pandemic is likely to have a lasting economic impact on many people. Meanwhile, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note—long a key economic barometer for financial markets around the world—barely budged in response to the report. The yield has been stuck in a narrow range for months, leaving some contending that the benchmark is losing its qualities as a window on the economy.

title: Riverstone’s $1.8 Billion Fieldwood Energy Investment Put at Risk by Bankruptcy
summary: Fieldwood Energy’s second bankruptcy in two years threatens a nearly $2 billion bet by Riverstone Holdings in the offshore driller.

title: Emerging and Growth Markets, August 8th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: Stocks Edge Up at End of Big Week
summary: U.S. stocks ticked higher as the latest employment report showed the economy added more jobs than expected last month, though uncertainty surrounding fresh government stimulus threatened to crimp a recovery.

title: Gulfport Warns on Risk to Business If It Can’t Refinance 2021 Debt
summary: Gulfport Energy said it might be unable to stay in business if it can’t refinance debt coming due next year, becoming the latest natural gas and oil company to face financial challenges during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Soybeans Fall as Bearish WASDE Expected
Pacific Drilling Considers Filing for Chapter 11
summary: The offshore oil and gas drilling contractor said it might file for bankruptcy and it has started talks with a group of creditors about a restructuring.

title: How a Tenuous Saudi-Russia Oil Alliance Could Melt Down
summary: Rebounding oil prices have the potential to show the cracks that already exist in the delicate cooperation between the powerful oil-producing nations

title: China Trade Rides a Wave in July After Coronavirus Restrictions Ease
summary: China’s exports picked up momentum in July for the second straight month, as global demand recovered with the easing of coronavirus-related restrictions.

title: Covid-19 Derails Latin America’s Bid for Middle-Class Prosperity
summary: The region faces a 9.4% GDP decline this year, the worst downfall on record, and will likely lag behind other emerging markets in any recovery. It’s a major blow for millions who were making the long climb out of poverty.

title: PE Daily: Sagard’s Latest Drug Bet | Calpers CIO Steps Down | Ares Rakes It In | ICG Sets Out to Raise €1 Billion for New Recovery Fund
summary: Earnings season has brought some confirmation to the idea that in times of great uncertainty, people stick with what they know and take fewer chances. So we see that some of the largest U.S. private-equity firms are rolling up record amounts of investment capital amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Glencore Scraps Dividend, Posts Loss as Coronavirus Saps Demand
summary: Commodities giant Glencore reported a loss for the first half of the year and scrapped its dividend, as the coronavirus pandemic sapped demand and lowered prices and production at its mining division.

title: Appeals Court Allows Dakota Access Pipeline to Continue Operating
summary: A federal appeals court said the Dakota Access pipeline can continue carrying oil for now, a win for pipeline operator Energy Transfer and North Dakota oil producers.

title: Lebanon Bonds Hold Ground After Deadly Explosion
summary: The deadly explosion that devastated Beirut left investors grappling with the potential damage to an economy already ravaged by crisis.

title: New York Lawmakers Seek Probe Of Puerto Rico Bondholders
summary: Five New York-based members of Congress are asking their state’s attorney general to probe whether investment firms that own billions of dollars in Puerto Rico bonds concealed aspects of their investments to manipulate prices and profit unfairly.

title: U.S. Stocks Rise on Stimulus Hopes
summary: U.S. stocks rose after White House negotiators said they aim to reach a deal on a new coronavirus-relief package by the end of the week.

title: How Big Should Government Let Big Tech Be?
summary: Instead of stifling the emergence of new products and services, Amazon, Google, Apple and Facebook have accelerated the rate of third-party innovation.

title: Noble Seeks to Pause Multibillion-Dollar Litigation Over Spinoff
summary: The energy company wants to  pause a multibillion-dollar trial over the 2014 spinoff of Paragon Offshore, a transaction creditors allege loaded up Paragon with old rigs and an unsustainable amount of debt.

title: Barrick Gold Considers Switching Primary Stock Listing to NYSE
summary: The Canadian mining company’s CEO said shifting to New York from Toronto would be a way to reach more investors, though there are currently no plans to make the move.

title: Antitrust Can’t Bust a Monopoly of Ideas
summary: Consumer-protection tools won’t be effective against the larger threat to American democracy.

title: Oil Prices Stay Higher After US Data -- Market Talk
Pandemic Lays Bare U.S. Reliance on China for Drugs
summary: Acetaminophen, antibiotics and high blood pressure treatments are among a slew of pharmaceutical ingredients made predominantly by China. Disruptions and high demand have expanded concerns about the supply of medicines.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Virgin Atlantic Seeks Bankruptcy Protection in U.S.; Bankruptcy Filings Soar in July; Mallinckrodt Warning
summary: Both personal and business bankruptcies surged 52% in July. And, more are lining up. Virgin Atlantic sought bankruptcy protection in the U.S. as part of a $1.5 billion restructuring plan; and offshore driller Fieldwood is the latest victim of the prolonged slump in the oil patch. Drugmaker Mallinckrodt warned that it may have to file for bankruptcy after an unfavorable court ruling surrounding the multiple-sclerosis drug Acthar.

title: Pandemic Hits Black-Owned Businesses Hard; Investors Pile Into Russian Government Bonds, Despite Emerging-Market Woes
summary: Businesses owned by Black people were hit especially hard by the coronavirus pandemic because of a combination of geography, limited reach of a key federal aid program and weaker ties to banks, according to research by the New York Fed. Outside the U.S., investors are flocking to Russian government debt, drawn by high yields and the country’s relatively strong finances compared with emerging-market peers. Thailand’s central bank kept rates on hold, the Monetary Authority of Singapore detailed plans for a new benchmark rate, and Sweden’s Rijksbank extended a swap agreement with the Fed.

title: Foreign Investors Flock to Russian Government Bonds
summary: After a feud with fellow oil exporter Saudi Arabia, Russia’s efforts to shore up its finances may be paying off.

title: Covid-19 May Keep Developing Countries From Catching Up to Rich Ones
summary: The coronavirus is making the growth of developing nations much rockier, potentially entrenching the divide between the world’s rich and poorer countries.

title: Beirut Explosion Caused by Fire Kills Dozens, Injures Thousands
summary: Dozens of people were confirmed dead and thousands more injured after a massive explosion caused by a warehouse fire rocked Lebanon’s capital city of Beirut.

title: Argentina Debt Deal Illustrates Coronavirus’s Blow to Emerging Markets
summary: Investors are bracing for more defaults and disruptions in emerging markets after Argentina’s deal with creditors highlighted the pandemic’s stress on many developing economies.

title: BP’s Vision for Life After Oil
summary: The oil-and-gas giant’s plan for a low-carbon future brings strategic clarity but financial uncertainty.

title: Offshore Driller Fieldwood Energy Files for Bankruptcy Protection
summary: Fieldwood Energy, an oil driller that operates in the Gulf of Mexico, filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday, the latest victim of the prolonged slump in commodity prices exacerbated by the pandemic.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Argentina Clinches $65 Billion Debt Deal; ’The Rock’ To Relaunch XFL; Bankruptcy Boot Camp For CFOs
summary: Argentina’s government is nearing a $65 billion restructuring deal with BlackRock, Fidelity and other big investors, resolving the country’s latest default without messy litigation, the WSJ reports exclusively. An investor group including Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson is poised to buy the XFL out of bankruptcy. And the coronavirus pandemic means that finance chiefs of distressed companies are getting a crash course in crisis management.

title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Jet Engine Overload, Refinery Demand Drops, Hidden Venice Treasures
summary: Grounded airline fleets with limited maintenance needs could depress engine makers’ revenues; U.S. fuel makers ran below capacity in the second quarter as demand shriveled, and trips to Venice were cancelled but its treasures can be found online.

title: Offshore Driller Fieldwood Energy Preps for Imminent Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Fieldwood Energy, an oil driller that operates in the Gulf of Mexico, is preparing to file for bankruptcy within days as it grapples with the prolonged slump in commodity prices exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Covid Supercharges Federal Reserve as Backup Lender to the World
summary: When the coronavirus halted the global economy in March, the U.S. central bank lent massively to counterparts abroad. The action—among its most significant expansions of power yet—cemented the dollar’s dominance.

title: Refiners Retrench as Demand for Gasoline, Jet Fuel Shrivels
summary: U.S. fuel makers ran below capacity in the second quarter in a preview of the challenges they are likely to face as the world transitions away from fossil fuels.

title: Coffee Drinkers Stay Home, Hitting Some Beans Harder Than Others
summary: The coffee bean market has bifurcated since lockdowns forced a shift in consumer behavior. Futures linked to arabica beans, which are popular in cafes and restaurants, have fallen much more than those tied to robusta beans, which are consumed largely at home.

title: PE Daily: White Rock Folds on Latest Energy Fund | Blackstone Gathers Capital Partners Fuel | Eyes on a Rail Deal
summary: Luis Garcia has an exclusive look at a rare event: the demise of a private-equity fund as investors rescinded their commitments. Also, Isaac Taylor has pulled together news on Blackstone’s latest fundraising drive for its Strategic Capital arm, which will fuel investments in other fund managers. Finally, Miriam Gottfried and Cara Lombardo broke news on Friday that a huge deal could be in the works for Blackstone and Global Infrastructure Partners.

title: Marathon to Sell Gas-Station Chain to 7-Eleven Owners for $21 Billion
summary: Fuel maker Marathon Petroleum agreed to sell its gas stations to the owners of the 7-Eleven convenience-store chain for $21 billion in the largest U.S. energy-related deal of the year.

title: White Rock Folds on Raising New Energy Fund
summary: The Plano, Texas-based private-equity firm sought to raise $250 million to $400 million for the fund, people familiar with the matter. said. This year, however, endowment managers grew concerned about a lack of progress in the fundraising as well as the high proportion of the fund’s capital Michigan’s endowment represented, the people said.

summary: Corrections & Amplifications

title: Gas Finds Trigger a Standoff in the Mediterranean Between an Isolated Turkey and Rivals
summary: The contest over newfound gas riches in the Eastern Mediterranean has triggered a slew of rival maritime claims, pushing the region’s main powers—all of them America’s partners or allies—toward open confrontation.

title: ‘New Normal’ Emerges for Companies in Pandemic
summary: Business executives say they are getting a better grip on what a world transformed by the coronavirus looks like, giving them more confidence to lay out new strategies.

title: Drillers Go Remote as Pandemic Reshapes Oil Business
summary: After cutting thousands of jobs during the coronavirus pandemic, the oil industry is accelerating its embrace of remote drilling and fracking, changes that will reshape its workforce permanently.

summary: Prime Day and iPhone shifts could mean a $100 billion sales quarter for each tech giant.

summary: Big tech keeps getting bigger despite concerns about their size and influence, smoking is making a comeback and now more than ever, consumers want to keep their houses clean.

title: Exxon Dividends: Jam Today, Jammed Tomorrow?
summary: The oil giant can manage its dividends, but it comes at a long-term cost that may not seem immediately apparent.

summary: The oil-and-gas company plans to hand ownership over to creditors as part of a bankruptcy strategy that would eliminate $2.1 billion in bond debt.

summary: Big oil companies endured one of their worst second quarters ever and are positioning themselves for prolonged pain as the coronavirus pandemic continues to sap global demand for fossil fuels.

summary: Noble, a London-based operator of offshore oil-and-gas drilling rigs, filed for bankruptcy, the latest victim of falling oil demand as the coronavirus pandemic ravages the global economy.

summary: The plunge seen in real interest rates could be bad news for stocks; slick oil trading has helped Royal Dutch Shell and Total earnings, and travel chaos may force tennis players to choose between the U.S. Open or the French Open.

title: Saudi King Leaves Hospital One Week After Surgery
summary: Saudi Arabia’s King Salman left a Riyadh hospital on Thursday after a 10-day stay that included an operation to remove his gallbladder, quieting speculation that his son might soon accede to the throne.

title: Shell Swings to Historic Loss as Pandemic Devastates Oil Demand
summary: Royal Dutch Shell swung to a heavy loss in the second quarter and warned that the outlook for oil-and-gas demand continued to be uncertain, illustrating the scale of the damage Covid-19 is wreaking on the industry.

title: Procter & Gamble Posts Biggest Yearly Sales Gain Since 2006
summary: Procter & Gamble, maker of household staples from Tide detergent to Charmin toilet paper, posted its strongest annual sales gain since 2006 as the pandemic kept consumers at home and vigilant about cleaning.

title: Offshore Driller Valaris Says Bankruptcy Filing Could Be Imminent

summary: As the Middle East prepares to celebrate Eid al-Adha, governments in the region are tightening coronavirus-related restrictions and urging people to stay at home to prevent a resurgence of infections.

title: John Bogardus Led Insurance Broker Through Rough Patch
summary: As CEO of insurance broker Alexander & Alexander, John Bogardus made a disastrous acquisition and struggled with an industry slump. He later wrote a history of insurance and concluded the golden age ended about the time he became CEO.

summary: Trading, retail and other formerly peripheral businesses will likely become increasingly important for integrated oil majors like Shell and Total.

summary: The riskiest bonds have been on the rise in Europe; new legislation would aid cash-strapped commercial-property owners, and industry experts saw a lasting decline in business travel, but think leisure travel will bounce back.

title: Wheat Futures Higher as Export Demand Appears to Rise

summary: Authorities in Belarus detained almost three dozen Russian nationals they say are military contractors who intended to destabilize the country ahead of the coming presidential election, in an incident that reflects increasingly strained relations between Minsk and Moscow.

title: U.S. Oil Inventories Plunge as Refinery Activity Speeds Up
summary: U.S. inventories of crude oil fell sharply by 10.6 million barrels to 526 million barrels last week as refinery activity picked up much more speed than expected, according to new data released by the EIA.

summary: Shale driller Denbury Resources is preparing to file for bankruptcy with a plan that cuts more than $2 billion in debt

title: The Daily Shot: Rental Vacancies at Multi-Decade Lows, but Mass Evictions Loom

summary: The price of carbon credits in Europe has rebounded from a pandemic low, reflecting government stimulus efforts and the reopening of economic activity.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Remington Files Ch. 22 Despite Surging Gun Sales | JPMorgan to Take Over Wine Country Resort | Neiman Creditors Detail Spinoff
summary: Despite surging gun sales, firearms and ammunition manufacturer Remington Arms fell into bankruptcy for the second time since 2018 after the collapse of deal talks with the Navajo Nation. The bankruptcy of a California real-estate business has put a wine-country resort and $475 million in tax assets within J.P. Morgan’s grasp. And creditors that looked into how Neiman Marcus Group’s private equity backers treated the company released their findings.

title: U.S. Stocks Start Week With Gains
summary: The S&P 500 closed higher, led by Apple and other tech stocks, while gold climbed to a record and the U.S. dollar dropped, reflecting investors’ concerns about the economy.

title: Rosehill Resources Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: pushed into bankruptcy amid low crude prices and disruption to the energy markets caused in part by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: PE Daily: Private Equity Places its 2020 Political Bets | SK Capital’s Polymers Carve-Out | Fundamental Advisors Aims for $1 Billion
summary: As we settle into the dog days of summer, the 2020 political campaigns are heating up and the private-equity industry is getting a piece of the action. In today’s newsletter I report on the huge sums private-equity executives have spent so far on 2020 races—some $92 million and counting—and which races and candidates the industry is backing. Next, WSJ Pro Private Equity’s Luis Garcia reports on SK Capital Partners’ deal for a unit of Baker Hughes Co., an oil field-services giant that has been hobbled by depressed commodities prices. And Isaac Taylor reports on another firm getting in on the recent booming demand for special-situations and distressed investing: Fundamental Advisors, which is seeking $1 billion for its latest fund.

title: Newsletter: Fiscal Cliff
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal.

title: Investors Set Aside Worries, Driving a ‘Melt-Up’ in Markets

summary: More than a third of the S&P 500 are expected to report their quarterly results this week, providing investors with a fuller picture of the coronavirus pandemic’s impact on U.S. businesses.

title: Covid’s Next Economic Crisis: Developing-Nation Debt
summary: Emerging economies like Zambia’s, already saddled by years of foreign borrowing, were ill-prepared for the pandemic’s financial pain. “You now have this really massive and all-encompassing shock.”

title: Saudi Arabia’s Latest Challenge: Containing Covid-19 During the Hajj
summary: As Saudi Arabia prepares to host the hajj pilgrimage next week, authorities face the unprecedented challenge of balancing their responsibility as stewards of the Muslim world’s most important religious event with the need to curb the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Everyone’s a Day Trader Now
summary: Bored, isolated and out of work amid the pandemic, millions of Americans are chasing stock-market glory—and bragging about it online. Not everyone’s a winner though.

summary: Leading oil-field-services companies Halliburton, Baker Hughes and Schlumberger have done themselves a favor by quickly confronting their new reality and ruthlessly cutting costs.

title: Schlumberger Cuts 21,000 Jobs Amid Historic Oil Downturn
summary: The world’s largest oil-field services company is cutting about 21,000 jobs as oil producers slash spending in response to a historic drop in prices amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: What Fed Officials Have Been Saying; Jobless Claims Rise as Data Points to Sputtering Economy; Russia Cuts Key Rate
summary: In the shadow of Thursday’s data showing a rise in U.S. unemployment claims, we take a look at recent comments by Fed officials and what they might reveal about their discussions on the economy at their meeting next week. Michael S. Derby has a roundup of economists’ views of the current state of the U.S. economy. Elsewhere, Russia’s central bank cut its key interest rate to a new low, and its counterpart in Turkey held rates steady.

title: Buy This Dubai Mansion, Get a Rolls-Royce, a Ferrari and a Harley, Too
summary: The 14,000-square-foot home on the Palm Jumeirah is asking $32.67 million.

title: Shipyards’ Rebound Hopes Are Coming Up Empty
summary:
Orders for new oceangoing ships are at record lows as carriers sit on the sidelines
            amid faltering trade demand during the pandemic and uncertainty over future ship-power
            technology.

title: Russia Cuts Interest Rates to Record Low
summary:
The central bank cut its key interest rate as the pandemic pushed the economy into
            a deep recession and forced President Vladimir Putin this week to delay a flagship
            $360 billion national development plan by six years.

title: United Airlines, Pfizer, Spotify Technology: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Stormy skies lie ahead for airlines, deal making in the energy sector shows signs of life and Americans’ remote working continues to drive strong sales for Microsoft.

title: Coronavirus Corruption Draws Public’s Ire in Latin America
summary:
As governments in Latin America respond to the coronavirus pandemic, corrupt officials

summary:
Speculators who have bet on natural-gas prices falling have been rewarded, and so
            have shareholders of the companies that have flooded the market with the dismally
            priced fuel.

title: Oil Nears 4-Month-High as Dollar Weakens -- Market Talk
PE Daily: The Resilience of Tech Funds | Riverstone’s $1.1 Billion Recap
summary:
Smaller businesses, especially those that rely on person-to-person interactions with
            customers, face tough choices, including shutting down or hitting the bankruptcy courts,
            as the coronavirus pandemic resurges in many parts of the U.S. But if that news isn’t
            troubling enough, there’s also the president’s move to send federal agents in battle
            fatigues into American cities while Congress dithers over extending relief efforts
            to ease the pandemic’s economic damage. If you get the sense that you’re walking into
            a fog these days, you’re not alone.

title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Oil and Gas Investing, Fake Businesses, Travel Plans
summary: Private-equity fund Warburg Pincus  said it won’t make any deals linked to fossil fuels from its next flagship fund; fake businesses fooled real banks into processing online drug purchases, and consumers decided to wait until the last minute to commit to a vacation.

The U.S. dollar fell for the fourth consecutive session, highlighting investor concerns
            about rising coronavirus cases in many states and aiding a booming rally in precious
            metals such as gold and silver.

title: Do Teachers Have an Excuse for Missing Class?
summary: Looks like a bad day for media narratives.

title: Kuwait’s Emir to Travel to U.S. for Medical Care; Saudi King Remains in Riyadh Hospital

title: PE Daily: Vistria’s St. Croix Eyes a Sale | Warburg to Shun Oil Deals | Carlyle’s Youngkin Steps Down as Co-CEO
summary: With the heat of summer upon us in the Northeast, you might expect deals and other newsworthy occurrences to slow. But no dice. Our Laura Cooper has an exclusive about a sale process percolating in the health-care sector while Luis Garcia reports that long-time oil industry investor Warburg Pincus plans to avoid fossil fuel-linked assets when it starts investing its next flagship vehicle. Meanwhile, our William Louch has news that Carlyle co-CEO Glenn Youngkin is leaving the firm.

summary: The blue-chip index climbed after earnings reports from major American companies provided fresh insights into how they are coping with the disruption caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

summary: Heath Tarbert has made it his mission to finish implementing several thorny parts of the Dodd-Frank Act, 10 years after the financial reform law was enacted.

title: PE Daily: Constellation Capital’s Adamson Looks Beyond Pandemic | KPS Eyes Another Industrial Rescue | Travelport Nears Deal to Cool Lender Dispute
summary: Around the country as the nation grapples with the challenges of reopening, some investors are beginning to think about what the post pandemic world might look like and their own role in helping businesses recover. Our Preeti Singh caught up with one such investor, David Adamson of Constellation Capital.

title: Shocked at Expensive Stocks? Bonds Might Be Worth a Look
summary: Shares in American companies are the most expensive they have been in almost 20 years. Bonds from American companies aren’t even as expensive as they were this February. Are corporate bonds offering a bargain that the stock market isn’t?

summary: Wirecard’s insolvency is inflicting pain on some banks who lent to the once-highflying German fintech.

title: Offshore Driller Noble Misses Interest Payment
summary: The company is in discussions with creditors to restructure $3.7 billion in debt.

title: PE Daily: Oil Patch Fundraising Dries Up | Cirque du Soleil May Spurn Investors
summary: The resilience of U.S. equity markets may belie sobering statistics, with investors focused six months ahead and the economic data reflecting the recent past. But those data sometimes come with more forward-looking elements, such as outlook surveys.

title: Ferries That ‘Fly’ Could Make It Easy—and Fast—to Travel by Boat
summary: An oil-trading billionaire and an Olympic sailor are adapting racing-boat technology for passenger ferries. Will they change maritime transportation?

title: Philly Fed’s Harker Sees ’Choppy’ U.S. Recovery; China Returns to Growth; Eyes on Lagarde
summary: Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker said the U.S. economy faces a choppy recovery, pointing to a “a very fluid forecast we are constantly revising.” China became the first major economy to return to growth since the onset of the coronavirus, saying its economy grew 3.2% in the second quarter. Indonesia’s central bank cut its key interest rate, while its counterparts in Canada and South Korea left theirs unchanged. And the European Central Bank will issue its latest policy statement this morning. The ECB is expected to hold monetary policy steady, so attention will be trained on President Christine Lagarde’s comments at her press conference.

title: Energy-Focused Firms Struggle to Raise Capital
summary: Institutional investors are avoiding traditional energy-focused funds due to low oil prices, poor returns and increasing concerns on the environment.

title: Newsletter: What Comes Next?
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal.

title: The Daily Shot: Americans Prepare for Homeschooling and Virtual Classes – Again
California Resources, State's Largest Driller, Files for Bankruptcy
summary: California Resources Corp., the state’s largest oil driller, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday to carry out a prearranged restructuring proposal that would wipe out more than $5 billion in debt and equity interests.

title: Oil Prices Rise on Vaccine Hopes, Falling Inventories
summary: U.S. crude prices hit a fresh 4½-month high with investors hoping for faster-than-expected coronavirus vaccine development and weighing a sizable drop in domestic crude stockpiles.

title: Surging Copper Prices Signal Optimism About Global Growth
summary: Global investors are piling into bullish wagers on copper prices, sparking the quickest rally in the industrial metal in years and signaling that many money managers remain hopeful about the economic outlook despite rising coronavirus cases in much of the U.S.

title: OPEC and Russia-led Oil Alliance Agree to Increase Production
summary: An alliance of crude producers led by Saudi Arabia agreed to increase oil production starting in August, officials in the group said, amid signs that demand is recovering following coronavirus-related lockdowns.

title: PE Daily: GPB Capital Rejects Massachusetts Fraud Claims | Bain Capital Makes Its Latest Insurance Move | WestView-Backed Paper Store Files for Bankruptcy
summary: As the surging coronavirus pandemic prompts more U.S. states to throttle back their economic and social engines, Singapore provided the world with a look at how dire the effects can be. The island nation at a global trade crossroads saw a record plunge in economic activity in the second quarter, becoming one of the first developed countries to detail the pandemic’s broad-brush impact. It’s jarring to consider what a similar decline would amount to in dollar terms here in the U.S., where much of the economy went into hibernation during the period and remains hobbled even now.

title: Newsletter: Walking the Coronavirus Tightrope
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal

title: Why Putin Loves America’s Greens
summary: Europe fast-tracks Nord Stream 2 as the left blocks U.S. pipelines.

title: Jump in Coronavirus Cases Could Jeopardize Oil Market Recovery, OPEC Says
summary: Even a record-breaking rise in oil demand next year won’t be enough to spur a recovery back to pre-coronavirus levels, according to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: EP Energy Proposes $4.4 Billion Debt-Cutting Strategy
summary: The oil-and-gas company floated a chapter 11 exit strategy that would hand the business to senior bondholders and cut $4.4 billion in debt, its second restructuring proposal after failing in a previous bid to leave bankruptcy.

title: Banks’ Energy Boycott Is an Antitrust Problem
summary: Radical groups organize an effort to starve oil and gas companies of capital. That raises prices for consumers.

title: PE Daily: Distressed Debt Takes On New Luster | Oprah Buys Into Blackstone-Led Oat-Milk Deal | Ackman Aims for $4 Billion
summary: The deals keep on coming, resurgent virus or not. Oatly, a Swedish company that makes a non-dairy milk alternative, has sold a stake to a Blackstone-led group that includes Oprah Winfrey and other celebrities, while a blank-check acquisition vehicle backed by Apollo agreed to buy Fisker in a deal valuing the electric-car company at about $2.9 billion. Speaking of blank-check companies, activist investor Bill Ackman has increased the fundraising target for his new vehicle’s IPO to $4 billion. Do we need to say that would be a record? And funds are flowing freely when it comes to distressed debt, as Chris Cumming reports. For these stories and more, please jump in

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Travelport Escalates Lender Feud | New York & Company Owner to Liquidate | Latam Creditors Slam DIP
summary: The feud between Travelport Worldwide’s lenders and private-equity backers shows no signs of abating as the company warned it could be forced into bankruptcy absent a favorable court ruling.

title: Fed’s Williams Plugs SOFR; Kaplan Sees Rebound Losing Momentum; U.S. Budget Deficit Tops $3 Trillion
summary: New York Fed President John Williams said the Secured Overnight Financing Rate, or SOFR—a replacement for the Libor interest-rate reference regime—has held up during the coronavirus pandemic. He also said progress is being made to move away from Libor and that it is time for firms to stop using it. Meantime, Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan said the resurgence of coronavirus is muting the U.S. economy’s recovery. And the U.S. government is on pace to post its largest annual deficit as a share of the economy since World War II.

title: Universities Cut Oil Investments as Student Activism Builds
summary: The movement to divest funds from fossil fuels at U.S. university and college endowments, which control more than $600 billion of investments, is gaining steam.

title: The Daily Shot: U.S. Job Postings Have Slowed Again
China’s Imports and Exports Rebound as Coronavirus Fades in World’s Second-Largest Economy
summary: Chinese imports from the U.S. rose for the first time since the new coronavirus emerged earlier this year, showcasing Beijing’s post-pandemic purchasing power even as political tension between the world’s two largest economies continues to rise.

title: OPEC Was Under Pressure Even Before Covid-19
summary: Even before the coronavirus pandemic upended global oil markets, the influence of OPEC—and the group’s revenues—were under pressure from competitors and the declining value of its crude, new cartel data show.

title: Netflix Can’t Afford a Weak Sequel
summary: The streaming giant’s share price has surged as Wall Street keeps betting on booming subscriber growth.

title: Silver Soars, Outpacing Recent Gains in S&P 500 and Gold
summary: Silver prices climbed to their highest level in nearly three years, lifted by factory reopenings and soaring investor demand for precious metals.

title: Hi-Crush Bondholders Poised to Take Over Frac-Sand Supplier
summary: Bondholders behind a proposed debt-for-equity swap include funds managed by Whitebox Advisors and PineBridge Investments.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: McClatchy Auction Tightens Hedge Funds’ Grip on Newspapers | Brooks Brothers Nets Zero-Interest DIP | AMC Inks $300 Million Rescue
summary: It’s been a busy few days for bankruptcy dealmakers. Hedge-fund manager Chatham Asset Management won an auction to buy McClatchy’s newspapers out of bankruptcy, bringing more of the U.S. print-news business under the control of financial investors.

summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal

title: Don’t Buy an Oil Fund With an Identity Problem
summary: Since its inception over 14 years ago, the United States Oil Fund has lost 95% of its value. You can’t just blame oil prices.

title: The Daily Shot: Volatility Markets Show Unease with Nasdaq 100
Who’s Excited About Tax Day? The Do-It-Yourself Filers
summary: Armed with just a calculator, brave Americans go mano-a-mano with the IRS’s 170-plus forms and instructions. ‘It was a fun exercise,’ one man said, after he spent 20 hours applying an arcane depreciation rule.

title: Frac-Sand Supplier Hi-Crush Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Hi-Crush Inc., a supplier of sand used in fracking, is the latest company in the oil and gas sector to be pushed into bankruptcy by low crude prices and the disruption from the coronavirus pandemic that has roiled the energy industry.

title: Morgan Stanley’s Presidio Tops Bidding for Bankrupt Templar Energy
summary: Morgan Stanley’s Presidio Petroleum was declared the winning bidder to buy Templar Energy out of bankruptcy for $91 million, significantly more than the company’s stalking-horse suitor had offered.

title: OPEC, Allies Set to Ease Oil Cuts
summary: An alliance of crude producers led by Saudi Arabia is pushing OPEC and its allies to increase oil production starting in August, officials in the group said, amid signs that demand is returning to normal levels following coronavirus-related lockdowns.

title: Emerging and Growth Markets, July 11th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: This Is What It Looks Like When a Texas Oil Boom Busts
summary: A year ago, the Permian Basin region was one of America’s hottest labor markets, fueled by a fracking gold rush. Today, the oil field has all but shut down, and everyone is feeling the pain, from restaurant owners to landlords to barbers.

title: B. Wayne Hughes Built a Self-Storage Empire. Now He Wants to Rent You a McMansion.
summary: Americans are giving suburban home rentals a new look as they search for affordable space during an economic downturn. A billionaire who made his fortune from storage facilities anticipated this moment nearly a decade ago.

title: Stocks Log Modest Weekly Gains
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 closed higher as investors brushed off worries about a fresh wave of coronavirus infections and its impact on the economic recovery.

title: Coronavirus’s Worst Impact on Oil Demand Has Passed, IEA Says
summary: The worst effects of the coronavirus on global oil demand have passed but will continue to echo as the market slowly recovers in the second half of 2020, the International Energy Agency said.

title: USDA Report: World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates
PE Daily: PE Deal Volume Plummets | Oaktree’s Airline Lifeline | Pandemic Alters Secondary Game
summary: Many U.S. readers may still be on vacation after the Independence Day holiday. For those at work, first-half fundraising and deal numbers are streaming in, and both are heading lower after the coronavirus brought travel to a halt and shifted deal-sourcing and due-diligence online. As Laura Cooper writes this morning, U.S. private-equity investments fell, with the dollar value of deals falling more sharply than the number of deals. Meanwhile, Oaktree Capital Management is offering a $1.3 billion bankruptcy lifeline to one of Latin America’s biggest airlines, and our latest survey of secondary investors illustrates how the pandemic quickly shifted buyer sentiment. Finally, Luis Garcia explains why the rebound in oil prices may not be enough to sustain private equity’s energy bets, even after many firms revamped their investment approach.

title: Garcia’s Take: Oil Still Hasn’t Rebounded Enough
summary: Most private equity-backed energy companies are having to turn profits by producing oil, instead of by exiting undeveloped fields.

title: Oxy’s Sweetener a Bitter Pill for Warren Buffett
summary: Occidental Petroleum’s surprise gift to shareholders such as Carl Icahn dents the value of the company’s lifeline from Berkshire Hathaway last year.

title: Newsletter: Growth Hinges on Containing Covid-19
summary: Your daily economics newsletter from The Wall Street Journal.

title: China’s Energy Policy Is a Darker Shade of Green
summary: China is simultaneously ramping up investment in both renewables and coal, raising uncomfortable questions for investors as well as climate activists

title: Goldbugs Take Center Stage in Markets, but the Real Show Is With Energy
summary: It’s getting harder to bet on a strong economic recovery. The wave of states opening back up has directly resulted in a wave of new coronavirus infections.

title: The Daily Shot: Sentiment Slumps Among Older Americans
